awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology to impact the 400,000 spinal fusion patients within the United States annually. Over the past ten years, spinal fusions have moved toward minimally invasive techniques supported by improved pedicle screws and better image guidance. These techniques have allowed smaller incision sizes, reduced tissue damage, and fewer misplaced pedicle screws. Despite these technical advances, studies have reported 10-40% of patients experience new or residual pain following spinal fusion. Moreover, 15% of patients need revision surgery within five years of their first spinal fusion. Smaller incision sizes have been linked to reduced patient back pain, time to ambulation, hospital length of stay, opioid use, and risk of surgical site infection. By creating tools tailored to the unique clinical needs identified by spinal surgeons, this technology can help these surgeons avoid complications and minimize the likelihood of pain and revision surgery. The development of smart tools offering surgeons greater degrees of intraoperative freedom can be expanded beyond the screwdriver, opening up a vast array of commercial applications in medical and surgical practice.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of technology to make surgical screwdrivers smart by offering neuro-navigation compatibility, high surgeon comfort and ease of use, retention of haptic feel, and angular feedback. This technology offers surgeons tools with greater degrees of freedom and this technology can be expanded beyond the screwdriver to different surgical tools and other medical procedures. The technology for screw placement in surgery is limited and relies on fixed screw delivery or difficult to control variable angle screwdrivers that offer a maximum range of 45°. Increased angular range for screw delivery improves a surgeon's ability to minimize the initial incision size, as well as decreasing the likelihood of expanding that incision or making secondary stab incisions. Increased incision size is associated with higher patient pain, increased likelihood of surgical site infections, and poorer patient outcomes. Moreover, the variable angle screwdrivers on the market cannot pair with neuronavigation to provide real time visual and quantitative feedback of location in the body. This screwdriver technology offers surgeons the ability to select the ideal angle of screw placement without sacrificing the reliability or stability of screw delivery. This work includes, but is not limited to, catheters in neurosurgical burr hole procedures, cement cannulas in orthopedic vertebroplasties, and scissors/cauterizers in abdominal surgeries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

por.por_cntn:
Spinal fusions permanently connect two or more vertebrae eliminating intervening motion in order to correct spinal deformities, stabilize weak spines and facilitate herniated disc removal. 400,000 spinal fusions are performed annually within the United States costing ~$50,000 per procedure. Spinal surgery is trending towards more minimally invasive procedures as smaller incisions reduce painful muscle and tissue damage leading to reduced patient back pain, time to ambulation, hospital length of stay, opioid use and risk of surgical site infection. We were devloping technologies to support controleld angulation of surgical instruments to perform spinal fusions.

 

Through the National I-Corps program, we hoped to learn how spinal fusions were performed across the spinal surgical space and understand our potential market as we iterated and advanced our technology. We conducted over 120 customer discovery interviews, including 50+ interviews with neurologic and orthopedic surgeons and 50+ interviews with spinal fusion system manufacturers. We attended five conferences with the support of the NSF I-Corps customer discovery grant: American Association of Orthopedic Surgeons (AAOS) Annual Conference, Spine Summit, American Association of Neurogical Surgeons (AANS) Annual Conference, Congress of Neurosurgeons (CNS) Annual Conference and Medical Design & Manufacturing (MD&M) West. The interviews and conferences allowed us to develop a much better understanding of the nuances of surgical technique and diversity of patient populaitons that exist throughout the United States; while helping us appreciate the unique challenges of marketing surgical tooling. These interviews caused our value propositions to change significantly, and even caused us to alter our target customer. We discovered that angulation of screwdriver instrumentation is a major limitation to reducing incision sizes, especially in patients with severe obesity (BMI > 35) and/or with complex anatomy (e.g. tight hips, high sacral slope).  Moreover, it is common for private practice and younger surgeons to elect not to operate on severely obese patients (25% of the 2030 US population) because increased incision depths, poor fat retraction and difficult anatomic obstruction make procedures longer, more strenuous and riskier. This is particularly important to surgeons in the Midwest and South who operate in competitive markets with an above average high BMI patient population. Frequently, high BMI patients are requested to lose weight prior to their procedure and are forced to seek multiple opinions until a spine surgeon, typically at a teritiary or quartenary care center, is willing to operate. Spinal instrumentation is typically offered to surgeons for free in order to sell spinal implants such as screws and cages. This indicates that there needs to be an especially high burden of evidence to support hospitals/surgeons acquiring an additional instrument. Meanwhile, competition between the major spinal fusion system manufacturers is fierce; and these companies are forced to develop new technology and mantain strong sales networks/customer relationships to mantain market share.

 

Since completing the NSF I-Corps program, we have used our learnings to iterate on our technology and guide future development. We have successfully placed a screw during in-vitro testing our instrument and were awarded a provisional patent by our university technology transfer office. Moreover, our improved business case was instrumental in us being awarded a $25,000 i3 Genesis manufacturing grant awarded by our intitutions technology transfer office. We are currently finilazing our minimal viable product for use in ex-vivo cadeveric testing and human factors testing with the spinal surgeon connections developed from our customer disvoery interviews. We will be submitting a Phase I STTR in 2024 with the foundation of our application foccused on next-generation improvements focussed on robotic and neuronavigation compaitibility that will position us to better sell to our customers according to our key learnings from the NSF I-Corps program.


The National I-Corps program has allowed us to position our technology to directly translate to improving care by creating the next generation of steerable surgical instruments to provide minimally invasive spinal fusions to patients with complex anatomy and/or high BMI.

 


Last Modified: 01/03/2024
Modified by: Jeremy   Steinberger
